question.name: 19.2.5.1 Recognising an exact equation
question.questiontext:
Recognising an exact equation

The equation \(\dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(yx)=3x^2\) is exact, as we have seen. If we expand the left-hand side of this equation (i.e. differentiate the product) we obtain \[ x \dfrac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}+y.\] Hence the equation \[ x \dfrac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}+y=3x^2\] must be exact, but it is not so obvious that it is exact as in the original form. This leads to the following Key Point:

Key Point

The equation \[ f(x){\mathrm{d}y\over \mathrm{d}x}+y\ f'(x)=g(x)\] is exact. It can be re-written as \[\dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(y\, f(x))=g(x) \quad\text{so that}\quad y\, f(x)=\int g(x)\, \mathrm{d}x .\]
